FFT.h

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 /**********************************************************************
00002 
00003   FFT.h
00004 
00005   Dominic Mazzoni
00006 
00007   September 2000
00008 
00009   This file contains a few FFT routines, including a real-FFT
00010   routine that is almost twice as fast as a normal complex FFT,
00011   and a power spectrum routine which is more convenient when
00012   you know you don't care about phase information.  It now also
00013   contains a few basic windowing functions.
00014 
00015   Some of this code was based on a free implementation of an FFT
00016   by Don Cross, available on the web at:
00017 
00018     http://www.intersrv.com/~dcross/fft.html
00019 
00020   The basic algorithm for his code was based on Numerical Recipes
00021   in Fortran.  I optimized his code further by reducing array
00022   accesses, caching the bit reversal table, and eliminating
00023   float-to-double conversions, and I added the routines to
00024   calculate a real FFT and a real power spectrum.
00025 
00026   Note: all of these routines use single-precision floats.
00027   I have found that in practice, floats work well until you
00028   get above 8192 samples.  If you need to do a larger FFT,
00029   you need to use doubles.
00030 
00031 **********************************************************************/
00032 /*
00033   Salvo Ventura - November 2006
00034   Added more window functions:
00035     * 4: Blackman
00036     * 5: Blackman-Harris
00037     * 6: Welch
00038     * 7: Gaussian(a=2.5)
00039     * 8: Gaussian(a=3.5)
00040     * 9: Gaussian(a=4.5)
00041 */
00042 
00043 #ifndef M_PI
00044 #define  M_PI     3.14159265358979323846  /* pi */
00045 #endif
00046 
00047 /*
00048  * This is the function you will use the most often.
00049  * Given an array of floats, this will compute the power
00050  * spectrum by doing a Real FFT and then computing the
00051  * sum of the squares of the real and imaginary parts.
00052  * Note that the output array is half the length of the
00053  * input array, and that NumSamples must be a power of two.
00054  */
00055 
00056 void PowerSpectrum(int NumSamples, float *In, float *Out);
00057 
00058 /*
00059  * Computes an FFT when the input data is real but you still
00060  * want complex data as output.  The output arrays are half
00061  * the length of the input, and NumSamples must be a power of
00062  * two.
00063  */
00064 
00065 void RealFFT(int NumSamples,
00066              float *RealIn, float *RealOut, float *ImagOut);
00067 
00068 /*
00069  * Computes a FFT of complex input and returns complex output.
00070  * Currently this is the only function here that supports the
00071  * inverse transform as well.
00072  */
00073 
00074 void FFT(int NumSamples,
00075          bool InverseTransform,
00076          float *RealIn, float *ImagIn, float *RealOut, float *ImagOut);
00077 
00078 /*
00079  * Applies a windowing function to the data in place
00080  *
00081  * 0: Rectangular (no window)
00082  * 1: Bartlett    (triangular)
00083  * 2: Hamming
00084  * 3: Hanning
00085  * 4: Blackman
00086  * 5: Blackman-Harris
00087  * 6: Welch
00088  * 7: Gaussian(a=2.5)
00089  * 8: Gaussian(a=3.5)
00090  * 9: Gaussian(a=4.5)
00091  */
00092 
00093 void WindowFunc(int whichFunction, int NumSamples, float *data);
00094 
00095 /*
00096  * Returns the name of the windowing function (for UI display)
00097  */
00098 
00099 const wxChar *WindowFuncName(int whichFunction);
00100 
00101 /*
00102  * Returns the number of windowing functions supported
00103  */
00104 
00105 int NumWindowFuncs();
00106 
00107 void DeinitFFT();
00108
